title: Time and Space Complexity
videoScript:
Hi, I’m Champak Roy and welcome to Programmer’s Picnic. In Lesson 2, we focus on Time and Space Complexity.

In this session we will:
• Understand the core ideas behind Time and Space Complexity.
• Look at Python code so the ideas feel concrete.
• Discuss typical interview or exam-style questions.
• End with practice problems and homework so you can apply what you learned.

Big picture: We introduce Big-O notation, walk through examples of O(1), O(n), O(n log n), and O(n^2), and talk about practical intuition instead of only formulas.

As you watch, keep a notebook or open editor ready so you can pause and try the examples yourself. Let's begin.
blogArticle:
## Lesson 2: Time and Space Complexity

In this lesson of *Programmer’s Picnic*, we explore **Time and Space Complexity**. We introduce Big-O notation, walk through examples of O(1), O(n), O(n log n), and O(n^2), and talk about practical intuition instead of only formulas.

### Why this topic matters

In competitive programming, interviews, and real projects, time and space complexity appear naturally. Being comfortable with this topic lets you:

- Model problems in a clean, structured way.
- Choose the right data structure or technique for constraints.
- Reason about time and space complexity so you do not over-engineer or under-engineer solutions.

### Core ideas

We cover the following ideas in this lesson:

1. Intuition and real-life analogies where possible.
2. Formal definitions and properties.
3. Python representations and idiomatic code.
4. Common pitfalls and how to avoid them.
5. Typical patterns in interview questions.

The best way to learn is to read the code, run it, and then modify small pieces to see what changes. Treat this lesson as a starting point, not the final word.
practiceProblems: Easy: A warm-up problem related to Time and Space Complexity to check basic understanding.
Medium: A slightly more involved problem that forces you to apply the main idea of Time and Space Complexity.
Hard: A challenging or interview-style problem that may combine Time and Space Complexity with previous topics.
homework: HW1: Implement at least two variations of an example from this lesson on your own, without copy–paste, and push them to your GitHub repository.
HW2: Write a short note or blog post in your own words summarizing what you learned about Time and Space Complexity.
HW3 (Optional): Pick a problem from an online judge (LeetCode / Codeforces / etc.) that uses this topic and solve it end-to-end.
